page.title: 18PONTSTICILL FOLKLORE
page.content: During the last century a young boy from Vaynor ensured a place for himself in local folklore.His name was William Berthllwyd;during the winter nights would hollow out turnips and carve faces into them and then place a small lit candle inside.He would then go down to the church before the evening service began and place his turnip in the hedge near by to scare the congregation who huddled together for safety.The vicar on arrival went to inspect the hideous face and found it was only the grinning turnip with William hiding nearby.William was duly locked in the shed whilst the service proceeded.After the service the vicar returned home for tea where he was presented with a plate of mashed turnip which reminded him of the incar cerated William.He was soon freed and allowed to go home with a warning.
